data.name: L1_Btn_AddedInst1
data.value: Do you know that all matter in the universe can be categorized as either a pure substance or a mixture? Pure substances have the same composition throughout. They can be classified as elements or compounds.

data.name: L1_Btn_AddedInst2
data.value: Elements cannot be broken down. Compounds are formed from the chemical combination of two or more elements. These elements cannot be separated by physical means. The properties of a compound are entirely different from the properties of each of the elements that make up the compound.

data.name: L1_Btn_AddedInst3
data.value: Mixtures are formed when two or more substances are physically combined. The parts of a mixture can be physically separated from one another. All of the substances in a mixture retain their original properties.

data.name: L1_Btn_AddedInst4
data.value: We’ll use these samples in the next experiment.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction1
data.value: Iron and sulphur are present in these chambers. Follow the instructions to form two new matters from iron and sulphur.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction2
data.value: In mixing chamber, iron and sulphur simply mixed together, no chemical reaction takes place.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction3
data.value: On heating iron and sulphur reacts chemically to form iron sulphide.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction4
data.value: Let’s classify these matters into element, compound and mixture on the basis of their compositions.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction5
data.value: Iron metal is made of only iron atoms. Thus it is an element.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction6
data.value: Sulphur is made of only sulphur atoms. Thus it is also an element.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction7
data.value: Iron sulphide is made up of two elements, iron and sulphur, chemically combined in a fixed proportion. Thus it is a compound.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction8
data.value: It represents a mixture of iron and sulphur as the constituent particles are not chemically combined together.

data.name: L1_Btn_Instruction9
data.value: Elements and compounds are pure substances as they contain only one kind of particles either atoms or molecules, whereas, a mixture contains two or more different kinds of particles.

data.name: L1_Inst_drag1
data.value: Drag and drop petri dish containing iron powder to highlighted spot to have its particle view.

data.name: L1_Inst_drag2
data.value: Drag and drop petri dish containing sulphur powder to highlighted spot to have its particle view.

data.name: L1_Inst_drag4
data.value: Drag and place petri dish containing matter obtained from mixing chamber to highlighted spot to have its particle view.

data.name: L1_Inst_SelectButton3
data.value: Select the highlighted button to collect the samples from both the chambers and place them on activity table.

data.name: L1_Inst_SelectYellowButton
data.value: Select the highlighted button to start mixing in mixing chamber.

data.name: L2_Inst_DragDropForSulphide
data.value: Drag and drop magnet over the watch glass containing iron sulphide to test its magnetic property.

data.name: L2_Inst_DragDropForSulphur
data.value: Drag and drop magnet over the watch glass containing mixture of iron and sulphur to test its magnetic property.

data.name: L2_Inst_DragDropGraduateCylForA
data.value: Drag graduated cylinder to beaker A and pour 20 mL carbon disulphide from it to beaker A.

data.name: L2_Inst_DragDropGraduateCylForB
data.value: Drag graduated cylinder to beaker B and pour 20 mL carbon disulphide from it to beaker B.

data.name: L2_Inst_DragDropSolutionBottle
data.value: Drag carbon disulphide solution bottle to graduated cylinder and pour 40 mL carbon disulphide from it to graduated cylinder.

data.name: L2_Inst_FollowInst
data.value: Follow the instructions to distinguish between iron sulphide acompound and mixture of iron and sulphur.

data.name: L2_Inst_IronSulphideMagnet
data.value: When magnet is moved over iron sulphide, no particle attaches to magnet.

data.name: L2_Inst_KeyConcept
data.value: Key Concepts ● The properties of a compound are different from the properties of each of the elements that make up the compound. ● In mixtures, all of the substances that make up the mixture retain their original properties.

data.name: L2_Inst_LetsTestBoth
data.value: Iron, as an element, is magnetic. Let’s test both the compound and the mixture to see if iron’s magnetism is maintained.

data.name: L2_Inst_MixtureOfBoth
data.value: In mixture of iron and sulphur, both yellow sulphur powder and iron filings are visible. Whereas, iron sulphide is having uniform appearance throught.

data.name: L2_Inst_MixtureOfIronSulphideMagnet
data.value: You can observe, in mixture, iron retains its properties, whereas in compound, iron has lost its properties.

data.name: L2_Inst_MixtureSulphurDissolves
data.value: You can observe, in mixture sulphur dissolves first and then reappears after some time whereas in compound no change is observed.

data.name: L2_Inst_MixtureSulphurRetains
data.value: Sulphur retains its properties in mixture, whereas sulphur has lost its original properties after reaction with iron.

data.value: Select the cap of carbon disulphide solution bottle to remove it.

data.name: L2_Inst_TakeaLook
data.value: Take a look at the appearance of both the iron sulfide and the mixture of iron and sulfur.

data.name: Level1
data.value: Exploring pure substances and mixtures

data.name: Level2
data.value: Distinguishing between substances and mixtures

data.name: ObjectiveContent
data.value:
Learning Objectives
After completing this module, you will be able to: ● Define pure substances. ● Define mixtures ● Distinguish between element, compound and mixture on the basis of their compositions. ● Sort given materials into pure substances and mixtures.

data.name: Title
data.value: Elements, Compounds, and Mixtures
